description.text:
Build your own bearing!!!  Bring your own bbs!
This linear bearing has four tubes that are filled with a number of bbs. The bearing has a cap that is held on with two screws.
I have now included the 1/4", the 6mm, and the 8mm versions of the bearing
External mounting is performed with zip ties passed around the decorative ribs on the bearing.
I designed this as a replacement for the linear bearings used within the reprap and maker community.
These bearings are louder than a standard bearing. It is important to note that using steel with copper is not the best solution. Steel shot are a better solution, but not as easy as bbs to get ahold of. besides........
These bearings only cost 35 cents to make. Including the copper bbs.

BB Circulator Version Now Released
Instructions
Bring Your Own BBs - Build Your Own Bearing
You can use either 1.77 mm bbs or find some 1.77 steel shot and make your own bearing. The bulk of the bearing is due to 3d printer limitations concerning walls.
I suggest printing at .2 layer height.
For ABS plastic, I suggest that you glue the bearing together with some Acetpaste. (Acetone and melted abs).
I prefer PLA for this bearing, as the strength adds to the life of the part.
The Circulator version has channels that use more bbs but help circulate them.  Do not overpack bbs.  Underpack by at least one, but dial this in due to bb diameter inconsistencies.
P.S. Out of everything I've built, I really think that this part is the most useful.

comments.text: I've been thinking that to make stuff like this, you should design it as closed, then pause the print at the right place to drop the bearings in.  Then resume the print and let it close it up...
comments.author: mmccool

comments.text: Yeah or on the newer MakerBot firmware there's a sleep function (cold pause) that will move the extruder head out of the way for you.  I'm sure this could be implemented on any other printer as well (Printrbot, RepRap, etc.)
comments.author: mmccool

comments.text: Sigh what Size BB's is this for 177mm??? I think not...
comments.author: jjhcs1

comments.text: If I'm not missing something, it looks like there's no place for the bearings to recirculate? If the bearings can't recirculate, they are probably just sliding over the rods instead of rolling. Adding a way for the bearings to recirculate would probably vastly improve their effectiveness.
comments.author: tlalexander

comments.text: aha, that might be why it takes so much wear.
comments.author: tlalexander

comments.text: Glad to help! I just thought I was missing something! But yeah, normally the balls can actually go in a loop around the bearing. Should be printable though! You've got a good start. :)
comments.author: moltenplastic

comments.text: I've uploaded a circulator version.  Overpacking is a problem, but you can dial it in.
comments.author: tlalexander

author: iCloud

description.text:
One piece of pie should be enough for any one, well this is for those who ate all the pie's Hah you thought I ran out'a ideas to get rid of all this gopping yellow. The cases are available here
https://www.3dagogo.com/3dagogo/designs/natkoPI2modBplusCase
https://www.3dagogo.com/3dagogo/designs/natkoPI2modBcase
Sorry need the cash

Print base plate and end plate for just 2 pieces of pie  
If your greedy print the link plates and expand to suit the number of slices of pie required.  
The thing's slot together before sliding the case in. Hopefully locking them together.   
No support, 2 wall's, 30% infill, 0.3 layer, nozzle is 0.46 on my printer, I also found that slowing print down prevented curling of the key ways (failing that a touch of filing n super glue might work)  
BTW the pictures are of straight of the printer (no touch up)

I love my Sodastream Penguin carbonator.  But the neck of the glass jars are kind of narrow for pouring from my Brita water filter.
So I needed a funnel.  Which I made to fit the bottle just right.

Print.
The OpenSCAD file is somewhat parametric, so you can make one that's a different size.
The goal is to create a juggling ball with led, electronics and battery in it. It will have to be printed as translucent. https://github.com/jeromelebel/LightJugglingBall ball.scad needs thread.scad.

Size in customizer and print out to hold your napkins. STL is for standard paper napkins.
This component is part of an open source lab library, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

I'm designing a DIY ukulele and wanted to try to print the nut and bridge.  PLA is hard enough that it might make a good material for it.
Design is based on the Stewart Macdonald soprano ukulele kit nut.  The OpenSCAD file is parametric and has some attempts at shaping the nut in the traditional manner.
I printed in white PLA with 100% infill so it can be shaped as needed.

comments.text: this is great ! if you ever made a bridge, can you post it ?
comments.author: robotsinc

description.text:
Thud Boardgame Since I got a 3d printer I wanted to make a THUD! boardgame.
I totally underestimated the effort it would take, but once things got rolling, there was no turning back.
I had played THUD! with a bought board already, and was disappointed with its tiny (/ugly) figures and the very small board that left almost no space between the figures to grab and move.
So I went BIG!
  • Data
    1 Mountainstone
    8 Trolls
    32 Dwarfs
    165 Base-Tiles
    165 Tile-Lids
    • approx.
    +200 hours of printing
    +15 hours of painting on the figures
    +3kg of material
    600 x 600 x 10 mm in size A. The figures
    So I started with the figures. The dwarfen clan from pocket tactics fulfilled all the dwarfish needs I had, and provides different dwarfes so my army wouldnt look as uniform. They needed to be scaled up, and since I didnt wanted to glue their halfes together I merged the halfes into standing pieces that printed without support properly. Once I hade the dwarfes, I had the scale for the rest of the game. With a 30mm base they needed board tiles with at least 45 mm width/length.
    The trolls ares loosely based on the rockfrog things I tinkered around with them in blender to make them more ... trolly.
    My wife painted the figures with meticolous details in full color, but I opted for a antique gold/silver/copper look halfway through, so sorry for the late decision honey. B. The board
    Here started the trouble. I took the 'Interlocking Board Game Tiles' Library, and scaled it up to 150% to fit my needs for 45mm tiles.
    The board became huge. And I had to print a ton of tiles for it. To achive a certain 'antique/used' look, I started to print the tiles on ABS slurry, black slurry for the white tiles and vice versa.
    The result is pretty nice. Because I use a dual-head printer (Leapfrog Creatr Dual Extruder), I wanted to make some special tile-lids for the initial positions of the figures.
    And for an 'antiqish' discworld boardgame I searched for celtic motives and found the trisquele and the triquetra. They are not neccessary for the game itself, but look great. C. The game
    You can find the rules and additional information on THUD! here:
    http://www.thudgame.com/ Video of the assembly: http://youtu.be/KKFpHoAtkRU EDIT:
    I forgot to include the thudstone in the files. Big sorry for this. Added it. May, 6th 2014

This is a LOT of work!
Figures can all be printed without support, if your printer is set up properly. You need to print
1 Mountain, 8 Trolls, 32 Dwarfs EDIT: Uploaded the slightly altered Dwarfen from the Pocket Tactics Set with dutchmoguls permission. Since the set cannot be added as a source due to its license, I provide the Link to the original set here.
LINK: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:61283 Boardtiles/lids should be scaled up to 150% coming to 45x45mm. You need to print: 165 Tiles, 165 Lids, color and style according to the scheme as seen in the images. You'll need the following set:
LINK: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4257

I was having an issue with uneven/uncontrolled cooling making larger prints split on my makerbot. So I made 4 little stands that hold a cardboard screen in place around the build platform. Works a treat.

Print out the stands.
Find 3mm cardboard (the box that my makerbot came in worked fine for me) and cut it to size (74cm x 18cm was what I used)
Fold the cardboard 25cm from each end and put the corner stands on.
Put the end stands on, put it in your makerbot, around the build platform and print those big prints worry free! I take it out for smaller prints and to clean the build platter.
